Strategy, reactions, lateral thinking, physics; it's all there.  You end up in your own kitchen wishing you could strike a portal to the dining room to avoid walking through with the dinner!  Brilliant game.
best game i have paled in years

I remember this game coming out way back in the day, but I was busy with other things and it was one of those games that just slipped past me.  My buddies would always reference it and I felt like I had played it even though I never did.  Well, I finally got around to it this summer.  And, to my surprise, it held up really well.  The puzzling was fun, but the commentary from Glados is what makes the game.  My daughter, who doesn't like video games, played along with me and we couldn't stop cracking up at the commentary.  We had so much fun I immediately purchased Portal 2 and we played through that.  While Portal 2 is a much more complete game, the simple fun of Portal 1 made it memorable.  I'm glad I finally got around to spending a couple hours with Aperture Science.

One of the best puzzle games I ever played, perhaps only bested by its sequel. An incredibly simple premise of setting up two portals to solve maze rooms, yet like the best of the genre it never gets old. New mechanics are drip-fed to you purposefully, but they never clog up the basic goal of setting up portals to escape. Its narrative is carried by one of my favorite antagonists in any video game: GlaDOS, whose monotonous inflection is in sharp contrast to her cold, bitingly sarcastic wit.

While Portal 2 improves upon this game in many aspects and is the better game, I still would highly recommend anyone to play this first. It's an incredible (if slightly short) puzzle shooter that flips the aggressive genre of FPS on its head, turning it into an intellectual, slow paced game of cat-and-mouse with an ominously sterile atmosphere.

4.5/5
